Submodules¶

pyproct.clustering.cluster module¶

Created on 12/03/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.cluster.Cluster(prototype, elements)[source]¶

Bases: object

A cluster object is defined a group of elements which have one or more characteristics in common and one element which is the most representative element of the cluster.

all_elements = []¶
calculate_biased_medoid(condensed_distance_matrix, elements_into_account)[source]¶

Calculates the medoid (element with minimal distance to all other objects) of the elements of the cluster which are in elements_into_account.

calculate_medoid(condensed_distance_matrix)[source]¶

Calculates the medoid for all_elements of the cluster and updates the prototype.

classmethod from_dic(cluster_dic)[source]¶

Creates a cluster from a cluster dictionary describing it (as reverse operation of ‘to_dic’).

@param cluster_dic: The cluster in dictionary form (output of ‘to_dic’)

get_random_sample(n, rand_seed=None)[source]¶

Returns a random sample of the elements.

@param n: Number of random elements to get.

@param rand_seed: Seed for the random package. Used for testing (repeteability)

@return: A random sample of the cluster elements.

get_size()[source]¶

Returns the size of the cluster (which is indeed the size of its elements list)

most_representative_element = None¶
set_elements(elements)[source]¶
set_prototype(this_one)[source]¶

Adds a representative element which must already be inside the internal elements list.

to_dic()[source]¶

Converts this cluster into a dictionary (to be used with json serializers).

pyproct.clustering.cluster.cluster_from_tuple(mytuple)[source]¶

Creates a cluster from a tupple formed by a first element being the prototype and a second element being the list of all elements.

pyproct.clustering.cluster.gen_clusters_from_class_list(group_list, skip_list=[])[source]¶

Generates the clusters that describe a group list. A group list for a N elements clustering is defined as the list of N elements with the number of cluster to which each cluster belongs. Example: for 4 elements [1,2,3,4] a possible group list would be: [2,1,2,1] which means that element 0 and 2 belong to cluster 2 and the others to cluster 2. As it’s not possible to define a centroid or medioid. ATENTION: the first element of the cluster will be defined as the centroid/medoid.

pyproct.clustering.cluster.get_cluster_sizes(clusters)[source]¶

Calculates all the sizes of a clusters list and returns it in a tuple in which the first element is the total number of elements, and the second a list containing the size of each cluster (maintaining the ordering).

pyproct.clustering.clustering module¶

Created on 20/03/2012

@author: victor

class pyproct.clustering.clustering.Clustering(clusters, details='', sort=True)[source]¶

Bases: object

Class representing the result of a clustering algorithm (a set of clusters).

add_cluster(cluster)[source]¶

Adds a cluster to the clusterization.

classmethod classify(tags, clusterings)[source]¶

Classifies a collection of clusterings using the classes in ‘tags’, counting the occurrences for each class. A clustering belongs to a class if in its ‘details’ string the class-tag appears.

@param tags: An array with the class-tags used to classify. @param clusterings: The list of clusterings to classify.

@return: A counter of the class occurrences.

cluster_index(cluster)[source]¶

Returns the index where the cluster ‘cluster’ is in the list ‘self.clusters’ or -1 if it’s not.

cluster_is_inside(cluster)[source]¶

Returns True if the cluster ‘cluster’ is currently in the clusters list.

eliminate_cluster(cluster)[source]¶

Deletes one cluster of the clusters list. The cluster has to be inside the list.

eliminate_noise(cluster_size)[source]¶

Deletes all the clusters with a number of elements under cluster_size.

classmethod from_dic(clustering_dic)[source]¶

Creates a clustering from a clustering dictionary describing it (as reverse operation of ‘to_dic’).

gen_class_list(starts_with=0)[source]¶

Generates a class list from a clustering.

get_all_clustered_elements()[source]¶

Returns a list with the elements in all its clusters.

get_medoids(distance_matrix)[source]¶

Returns a list containing the medoids of all clusters.

@param distance_matrix: Is the distance matrix used to calculate the clustering.

@return: The list of medoids.

get_population_percent_of_cluster(i)[source]¶

Returns the percentage of elements of this cluster over the number of all the elements of the dataset used to get the clusters (total_elements).

get_population_percent_of_n_bigger_clusters(n)[source]¶

Gets the percentage of population over total population of the first n bigger modules.

get_proportional_size_representatives(number_of_structures, distance_matrix)[source]¶

Returns a list with the medoids and a random sample of cluster elements so that the number of elements of each cluster in the list is proportional to the size of each cluster.

@param number_of_structures: Is the final number of elements we want in our list.

@param distance_matrix: Is the distance matrix used to calculate the clustering.

@return: The list of representative elements.

classmethod load_all_from_directory(directory)[source]¶

Loads all clusterings residing in a directory.

@param directory: The directory path.

@return: The list of loaded clusterings (with their filenames) inside this directory.

classmethod load_from_disk(path_with_file_name)[source]¶

Loads a clustering which was stored into disk.

@param path_with_file_name: complete path with name of the file (the same used for saving).

@return: The clustering stored in this file.

number_of_clusters_to_get_percent(percent)[source]¶

Returns the number of clusters needed to get the percentage ‘percent’ over total_elements.

save_to_disk(path_with_file_name)[source]¶

Saves itself as a binary file.

@param filename: complete path with name of the file

sort_clusters_by_size(reverse=True)[source]¶

Returns a list o sorted clusters by size of the cluster. The biggest cluster goes first unless reverse = False.

to_dic()[source]¶

Converts this clustering into a dictionary (to be used with json serializers).
